sen.j: 陣幕 久五郎（じんまく きゅうごろう、文政12年5月3日 (旧暦)（1829年6月4日） - 明治36年（1903年）10月21日）は、江戸時代の相撲力士。
sen.e: Kyugoro JINMAKU (June 4, 1829 - 21 October, 1903) was sumo wrestler of the Edo period.
Kyugoro JINMAKU (June 4, 1829 - 21 October, 1903) was sumo wrestler of the Edo period.
Kyugoro JINMAKU (June 4, 1829 - 21 October, 1903) was sumo wrestler of the Edo period.

sen.j: 第12代横綱。
sen.e: He was the 12th Yokozuna (sumo grand champion).
He was the 12th Yokozuna (sumo grand champion).
He was the 12th Yokozuna (sumo grand champion).

sen.j: 江戸時代に横綱免許を受けた最後の力士である。
sen.e: He was the last sumo wrestler who received a Yokozuna license during the Edo period.
He was the last sumo wrestler who received a Yokozuna license during the Edo period.
He was the last sumo wrestler who received a Yokozuna license during the Edo period.

sen.j: 「負けず屋」のあだ名で知られた強豪横綱。
sen.e: He was a very strong Yokozuna with a nickname of 'Mr. Never-Lost'.
He was a very strong Yokozuna with a nickname of 'Mr. Never-Lost'.
He was a very strong Yokozuna with a nickname of 'Mr. Never-Lost'.

sen.j: 史上横綱十強に入れる人も多い。
sen.e: He is sometimes counted as one of the 10 strongest Yokozuna in the history.
He is sometimes counted as one of the 10 strongest Yokozuna in the history.
He is sometimes counted as one of the 10 strongest Yokozuna in the history.

sen.j: 身長174cm、体重138kgと伝わる。
sen.e: He was said to be 1.74m tall and weighed 138Kg.
It has been said that he was 174 centimeters in height and weighed 138 kilograms.
It has been said that he was 174 centimeters in height and weighed 138 kilograms.

sen.j: 出雲国意宇郡（現・島根県八束郡東出雲町）出身。
sen.e: Jinmaku was born in Ou-no-kori, Izumo Province (current Higashi Izumo cho, Yatsuka gun, Shimane Prefecture).
Jinmaku was from Ou-no-kori, Izumo Province (current Higashi-Izumo-cho, Yatsuka County, Shimane Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 用語を統一します。日本人や中国人の「出身」は生地を意味しないのでfromが無難です。
sen.e: Jinmaku was from Ou-no-kori, Izumo Province (current Higashi-Izumo-cho, Yatsuka County, Shimane Prefecture).

sen.j: 本名は石倉槇太郎という。
sen.e: His real name was Shintaro ISHIGURA.
sen.cmt: 「石倉」が「いしくら」か「いしぐら」かは不明です。http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jinmaku_Ky%C5%ABgor%C5%8Dには「いしぐら」とありました。
sen.e: His real name was Shintaro ISHIGURA.
His real name was Shintaro ISHIGURA.

sen.j: 1847年（弘化4年）、広島県尾道の力士初汐久五郎の弟子となる。
sen.e: In 1847, he became a pupil of a wrestler Kyugoro HATSUSHIO of Onomichi, Hiroshima Prefecture.
In 1847, he became a pupil of a wrestler Kyugoro HATSUSHIO of Onomichi, Hiroshima Prefecture.
In 1847, he became a pupil of a wrestler Kyugoro HATSUSHIO of Onomichi, Hiroshima Prefecture.

sen.j: その力量を認められ黒縅槙之助と名乗った。
sen.e: His skill was approved and he changed his name to Makinosuke KUROODOSHI.
His skill was approved and he changed his name to Makinosuke KUROODOSHI.
His skill was approved and he changed his name to Makinosuke KUROODOSHI.

sen.j: 1848年（嘉永元年）、初汐が没したため大阪に出て、朝日山四郎右衛門の門人となる。
sen.e: When Hatsushio died in 1848, Jinmaku moved to Osaka and became a pupil of Shiroemon ASAHIYAMA.
When Hatsushio died in 1848, Jinmaku moved to Osaka and became a pupil of Shiroemon ASAHIYAMA.
When Hatsushio died in 1848, Jinmaku moved to Osaka and became a pupil of Shiroemon ASAHIYAMA.

sen.j: 1850年（嘉永3年）大坂相撲で初土俵を踏む。
sen.e: In 1850, he had his first sumo bout in Osakazumo (Osaka Sumo).
In 1850, he had his first sumo bout in Osakazumo (Osaka Sumo).
In 1850, he had his first sumo bout in Osakazumo (Osaka Sumo).

sen.j: 新入幕は1858年（安政5年）正月場所。
sen.e: He got into the Makuuchi (top) division at the New Year tournament in 1858.
He was raised to the Makuuchi (top) rank at the New Year tournament in 1858.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: He was raised to the Makuuchi (top) rank at the New Year tournament in 1858.

sen.j: 嘉永3年（1850年）江戸に出て、秀の山雷五郎（9代横綱）の門人となる。
sen.e: In 1850, he moved to Edo (Tokyo) and became a pupil of Raigoro HIDENOYAMA (the ninth Yokozuna).
In 1850, he moved to Edo (Tokyo) and became a pupil of Raigoro HIDENOYAMA (the ninth Yokozuna).
In 1850, he moved to Edo (Tokyo) and became a pupil of Raigoro HIDENOYAMA (the ninth Yokozuna).

sen.j: 徳島藩の抱え相撲力士として出発したが、途中で一時期松江藩の抱え力士となり、1864年（元治元年）10月以降は薩摩藩の抱え力士となった。
sen.e: He started as a (Sumo) wrestler of Tokushima Domain, temporarily was a wrestler of Matsue Domain, then became a wrestler of Satsuma Domain from October 1864.

He began his career as a retained Sumo wrestler of the Tokushima clan, however during the term, he temporarily served as a retained wrestler of the Matsue clan, then from October of 1864, he became a retained wrestler of the Satsuma clan.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: He began his career as a retained Sumo wrestler of the Tokushima clan, however during the term, he temporarily served as a retained wrestler of the Matsue clan, then from October of 1864, he became a retained wrestler of the Satsuma clan.

sen.j: このことが、明治以降における陣幕の活動を助けることとなる。
sen.e: This shifting helped Jinmaku's activity during the Meiji period.
This shifting helped Jinmaku's activity during the Meiji period.
This shifting helped Jinmaku's activity during the Meiji period.

sen.j: ただし、この度重なる所属替えは徳島藩士の陣幕への嫌悪へとつながり、1867年（慶応3年）4月場所7日目の陣幕と張出小結鬼面山谷五郎との取組で最高潮に達した。
sen.e: However, constant change of Domains caused the Tokushima Domain's distaste of him, which became the worst at the bout between Jinmaku and Tanigoro KIMENZAN of Haridashi Komusubi (one of the sumo wrestlers of the fourth highest rank) on the seventh day of the April Tournament in 1867.

However, his perpetual transfers caused the hatred of the retainers of the Tokushima clan, which burst up at the match between Jinmaku and Haridashi-Komusubi (wrestler at the fourth highest rank, lower grade) Tanigoro KIMENZAN on the seventh day of the April Tournament in 1867.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: However, his perpetual transfers caused the hatred of the retainers of the Tokushima clan, which burst up at the match between Jinmaku and Haridashi-Komusubi (wrestler at the fourth highest rank, lower grade) Tanigoro KIMENZAN on the seventh day of the April Tournament in 1867.

sen.j: 対する鬼面山は新入幕以来徳島藩の抱え力士で、陣幕とともに阿波の四天王と称されたこともある強豪力士であり、陣幕は幕末の勢いに乗る薩摩藩抱えであった。
sen.e: Kimenzan had been of the Tokushima Domain since getting on the Makuchi ranking and he was a strong wrestler once being called Shitenno (The Big Four) of Awa together with Jinmaku; and Jinmaku was of the Satsuma Domain which was building on the momentum at the end of the Edo period.

Kimenzan had been a retained wrestler of the Tokushima clan since joining the Makuchi rank and he was a strong wrestler once called Shitenno (The Big Four) of Awa together with Jinmaku; and Jinmaku was of the Satsuma clan which was building on the momentum at the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: Kimenzan had been a retained wrestler of the Tokushima clan since joining the Makuchi rank and he was a strong wrestler once called Shitenno (The Big Four) of Awa together with Jinmaku; and Jinmaku was of the Satsuma clan which was building on the momentum at the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 土俵脇の砂かぶりでは両藩士が刀の柄に手をかけ、行司式守伊之助も顔面蒼白という一触即発の雰囲気の中、両力士は待った2度、水入り2度ののちに引き分けた。
sen.e: While feudal retainers of both domains were standing the Sunakaburi (lit. sand-covered) seats right next to the ring with their hands on the handle of their swords and the referee Inosuke SHIKIMORI looked as white as a sheet, both wrestlers fought in a touch and go situation; after 2 Matta (false starts of the sumo bout) and 2 Mizuiri (breaks granted to sumo wrestlers engaged in a prolonged bout), they ended in a draw.

In the explosive atmosphere as the retainers of both clans were glaring at each other at the Sunakaburi (lit. sand-covered seats) right next to the ring with their hands on their swords hilts, and the referee Inosuke SHIKIMORI's face white as a sheet, both wrestlers fought and after the referee called Matta (false start of a match) twice and Mizuiri (break granted to wrestlers during a prolonged match) twice, the match ended in a draw.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: In the explosive atmosphere as the retainers of both clans were glaring at each other at the Sunakaburi (lit. sand-covered seats) right next to the ring with their hands on their swords hilts, and the referee Inosuke SHIKIMORI's face white as a sheet, both wrestlers fought and after the referee called Matta (false start of a match) twice and Mizuiri (break granted to wrestlers during a prolonged match) twice, the match ended in a draw.

sen.j: 水入りの際の場内の騒ぎは、天地も崩れるほどであったという。
sen.e: The noise the audience made at each Mizuiri was like thunder cracking the place.
The noise the audience made at each Mizuiri was like thunders roaring the place.
The noise the audience made at each Mizuiri was like thunders roaring the place.

sen.j: 1866年（慶応2年）11月場所に大関となり、1867年（慶応3年）正月に五条家から、同年10月に吉田司家から横綱免許を授与された。
sen.e: Jinmaku became Ozeki (the second highest rank) in the November Tournament in 1866 and he was awarded with Yokozuna licenses, initially from the Gojo family at the New Year of 1867 and from the Yoshida-tsukasa family in October of the same year.

Jinmaku became Ozeki (the second highest rank) in the November Tournament in 1866 and he was awarded with Yokozuna licenses, initially from the Gojo family at the New Year of 1867 and from the Yoshida-tsukasa family in October of the same year.

Jinmaku became Ozeki (the second highest rank) in the November Tournament in 1866 and he was awarded with Yokozuna licenses, initially from the Gojo family at the New Year of 1867 and from the Yoshida-tsukasa family in October of the same year.

sen.j: しかし、相撲を取ったのは慶応3年11月場所までで、その後は明治維新の動乱に巻き込まれた。
sen.e: However, he only wrestled until the November Tournament in 1867 and after that he was involved in the turbulent of the Meiji Restoration.
However, he only wrestled until the November Tournament in 1867 and after that he was involved in the turbulent of the Meiji Restoration.
However, he only wrestled until the November Tournament in 1867 and after that he was involved in the turbulent of the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 通算成績は幕内19場所87勝5敗17分3預65休、勝率.946。
sen.e: His record in the top division was: 19 Tournaments, 87 wins, 5 losses, 17 draws, 3 holds and 65 absences; winning rate 94.6%.
His record in the top rank was 19 tournaments, 87 wins, 5 defeats, 17 draws, 3 holds and 65 absences; winning average 94.6%
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: His record in the top rank was 19 tournaments, 87 wins, 5 defeats, 17 draws, 3 holds and 65 absences; winning average 94.6%

sen.j: 優勝相当成績5回。
sen.e: He got 5 titles which are equivalent to the Championship level today.
He got 5 titles which are equivalent to the Championship level today.
He got 5 titles which are equivalent to the Championship level today.

sen.j: 結果的にではあるが、横綱勝率10割【1867年（慶応3年）3月7勝2分、同年11月7勝。計14勝2分無敗】という永遠に破られないであろう記録を打ち立てた。
sen.e: As Yokozuna, his winning average was 100% (7 wins and 2 draws in April 1867 and 7 wins in November the same year, a total of 14 wins, 2 draws and no losses); he established an impossible record to beat.

As Yokozuna, his winning average was 100% (7 wins and 2 draws in March of 1867 and 7 wins in November of the same year, which brings the number of win to 14, draws to 2 and no defeat); so as a result he established a great record which would be never broken.
sen.cmt: 写し間違い、訳漏れがあります。
sen.e: As Yokozuna, his winning average was 100% (7 wins and 2 draws in March of 1867 and 7 wins in November of the same year, which brings the number of win to 14, draws to 2 and no defeat); so as a result he established a great record which would be never broken.

sen.j: 1867年（慶応3年）12月25日、江戸・三田の薩摩藩邸焼討事件の直前に偶然近くを通り、藩邸への襲撃を予感して、藩抱え力士を召集し、藩邸に戻った。
sen.e: When he coincidently walked past the Hantei (residence) of Satsuma clan in Mita, Tokyo on January 19, 1868 just before it was lit, he had a premonition of that; so he collected all the wrestlers of the Domain and went back to the residence.

On December 25, 1867 (in old lunar calender), just before the attack against the residence of the Satsuma clan of Mita in Edo, he walked near the residence by accident; he had a premonition and called fellow retained wrestlers and went back to the residence with them.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: On December 25, 1867 (in old lunar calender), just before the attack against the residence of the Satsuma clan of Mita in Edo, he walked near the residence by accident; he had a premonition and called fellow retained wrestlers and went back to the residence with them.

sen.j: 既に藩邸は庄内藩士らによって焼き討ちされていたため、陣幕は川崎まで走って、知人に大坂の西郷隆盛に手紙を送るよう頼んだ。
sen.e: However, the Hantei was already burnt down by samurai of Shonai Domain, so he ran all the way to Kawasaki to ask a friend to write to Takamori SAIGO in Osaka.

However, the residence was already set fire and attacked by the retainers of the Shonai clan, so Jinmaku ran all the way to Kawasaki to ask his acquaintance to write to Takamori SAIGO (a retainer of the Satsuma clan) who was staying in Osaka.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: However, the residence was already set fire and attacked by the retainers of the Shonai clan, so Jinmaku ran all the way to Kawasaki to ask his acquaintance to write to Takamori SAIGO (a retainer of the Satsuma clan) who was staying in Osaka.

sen.j: この手紙は、1868年（明治元年）1月2日(旧暦)の朝に西郷に届いた。
sen.e: The letter reached Saigo in the morning of February 2, 1868.
The letter reached Saigo in the morning of January 2, 1868 (in old lunar calendar).
The letter reached Saigo in the morning of January 2, 1868 (in old lunar calendar).

sen.j: 戊辰戦争では京都に上って薩摩藩主島津忠義の護衛をするなどした。
sen.e: At the Boshin War, Jinmaku went to Kyoto to protect Tadayuki SHIMAZU, the lord of the Satsuma Domain.
At the Boshin War, Jinmaku went to Kyoto to protect Tadayoshi SHIMAZU, the lord of the Satsuma Domain.
sen.cmt: 写し間違いがあります。
sen.e: At the Boshin War, Jinmaku went to Kyoto to protect Tadayoshi SHIMAZU, the lord of the Satsuma Domain.

sen.j: その後、年寄陣幕として大坂相撲の発展に尽くしたが、1880年（明治13年）9月場所限りで廃業し、実業家に転進した。
sen.e: After that, he was involved deeply in the development of Osakazumo as Toshiyori (retired wrestler's title) but decided to withdraw in the September Tournament in 1880 and became a business man.

After that, he was involved deeply in the development of Osakazumo as Toshiyori (retired wrestler), however he resigned at the end of the September Tournament of 1880 and withdrew from the sumo world, and became a business man.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: After that, he was involved deeply in the development of Osakazumo as Toshiyori (retired wrestler), however he resigned at the end of the September Tournament of 1880 and withdrew from the sumo world, and became a business man.

sen.j: 特に相撲関係の建碑事業に奔走し、1900年（明治33年）に建立した東京・深川の富岡八幡宮の「横綱力士碑」など、全国各地に碑を建てた。
sen.e: He was busy especially in erecting Sumo Memorial Monuments and built so many in many places in Japan including the Yokozuna Rikishi Memorial Monument in the Tomioka Hachimangu Shrine in Fukagawa, Tokyo in 1900.

He devoted himself especially to erect memorial monuments to sumo and built monuments in many places in Japan including the 'Yokozuna Rikishi Memorial Monument' in Tomioka Hachimangu Shrine in Fukagawa, Tokyo in 1900.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: He devoted himself especially to erect memorial monuments to sumo and built monuments in many places in Japan including the 'Yokozuna Rikishi Memorial Monument' in Tomioka Hachimangu Shrine in Fukagawa, Tokyo in 1900.

sen.j: そうしたことから「建碑狂」とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: This earned him a nickname of 'Monument Head'.
This earned him a nickname of 'Kenpikyo' (electing monuments maniac).
This earned him a nickname of 'Kenpikyo' (electing monuments maniac).

sen.j: 元勲元老を始めとする政財官界の大物が協力しており、薩摩藩抱えであった経歴を十二分に活用している。
sen.e: Many politicians, businessmen and bureaucrats such as Genkun (the statemen who contributed in Meiji Restoration) and Genro (elder chairmen) co-operated in his business, which means that he used his career of belonging the Satsuma Domain efficiently.

Many politicians, businessmen and bureaucrats such as Genkun (the statemen who contributed in Meiji Restoration) and Genro (elder chairmen) co-operated in his business, which means that he fully used his career as an ex-retained wrestler of the Satsuma clan.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: Many politicians, businessmen and bureaucrats such as Genkun (the statemen who contributed in Meiji Restoration) and Genro (elder chairmen) co-operated in his business, which means that he fully used his career as an ex-retained wrestler of the Satsuma clan.

sen.j: 1887年（明治20年）5月の靖国神社大祭奉納相撲では土俵入りを奉納した。
sen.e: He dedicated his Dohyo-iri (ring-entering ceremony) at Honozumo (ritual Sumo matches) held at Yasukuni-jinja Shrine in May, 1887.
He dedicated his Dohyo-iri (ring-entering ceremony) at Honozumo (ritual Sumo matches) held at Yasukuni-jinja Shrine in May, 1887.
He dedicated his Dohyo-iri (ring-entering ceremony) at Honozumo (ritual Sumo matches) held at Yasukuni-jinja Shrine in May, 1887.

sen.j: 1895年（明治28年）に力士としては初の自伝である「陣幕久五郎通高事跡」を上梓した。
sen.e: He published the first autobiography by a Sumo wrestler called 'Junmaku Kyugoro Michitaka's Jiseki' (Jinmaku's Achievement) in 1895.
In 1895 he published 'Junmaku Kyugoro Michitaka's Jiseki' (Jinmaku's Achievement) which was the first autobiography sumo wrestler had ever written.
In 1895 he published 'Junmaku Kyugoro Michitaka's Jiseki' (Jinmaku's Achievement) which was the first autobiography sumo wrestler had ever written.

sen.j: 1901年（明治34年）11月の靖国神社社殿竣工式でも土俵入りを奉納している。
sen.e: In November, 1901, he again dedicated his Dohyo-iri at the shunkoshiki (ceremony of completion) of the main building of Yasukuni-jinja shrine.
In November, 1901, he again presented his Dohyo-iri at the ceremony to celebrate the completion of the main building of Yasukuni-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: In November, 1901, he again presented his Dohyo-iri at the ceremony to celebrate the completion of the main building of Yasukuni-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 晩年は東両国の火除地で横綱煎餅を売っていたらしい。
sen.e: In his later years, he was said to be selling Yokozuna Senbe (Yokozuna rice crackers) in a shady spot in Higashi-Ryogoku town.
It has been said that in his later years, he was selling Yokozuna Senbe (Yokozuna rice crackers) at the open in Higashi-Ryogoku town.
sen.cmt: 原文に「日除け地」とありましたが、「火除地」（避難場所用空き地で普段はみんなの広場）の間違いですので直します。
sen.e: It has been said that in his later years, he was selling Yokozuna Senbe (Yokozuna rice crackers) at the open in Higashi-Ryogoku town.

sen.j: 1903年（明治36年）10月21日、数え75歳で没。
sen.e: He died on October 21, 1903 at the age of 74.
He died on October 21, 1903 at the age of 74.
He died on October 21, 1903 at the age of 74.

sen.j: 遺言に従って、檜製の棺に横綱が巻きつけられた。
sen.e: According to his will, a Yokozuna rope was tied around his wooden coffin.
According to his will, a Yokozuna rope was tied around his hinoki coffin.
sen.cmt: 「檜」とわざわざあるので訳に入れます。
sen.e: According to his will, a Yokozuna rope was tied around his hinoki coffin.

sen.j: 錦絵も写真も眼光鋭い陣幕の様子を描写しており、威圧感は十分だった。
sen.e: The Nishiki-e (colored woodblock print) of Jinmaku shows his sharp-looking eyes and we can say that he must have intimidated people easily.
The Nishiki-e (colored woodblock print) and photo of Jinmaku shows his piercing eyes which must have intimidated people easily.
The Nishiki-e (colored woodblock print) and photo of Jinmaku shows his piercing eyes which must have intimidated people easily.

sen.j: ただ、初めのうちは皆弱いと思っていたため、弾みで「生首をやる」とか言って後で必死に謝る羽目になった者がいたり、不知火光右衛門に鼻であしらわれ絶対勝たせなかったりした。
sen.e: Yet, at first he did not look strong so some wrestlers boasted on 'severing his head' and ended up apologizing when they could not; and after he was snubbed by Mitsuemon SHIRANUI, he never gave Shiranui a chance to win.
sen.cmt: 「不知火光右衛門に鼻であしらわれ絶対勝たせなかったりした」の部分の仮訳です。
sen.e: However, at first he did not look strong, so some wrestler, who had been boasting that he would cut his head off, ended up apologizing desperately, and Mitsuemon SHIRANUI, who had snubbed him, was never given even a slight chance to win.

However, at first he did not look strong, so some wrestler, who had been boasting that he would cut his head off, ended up apologizing desperately, and Mitsuemon SHIRANUI, who had snubbed him, was never given even a slight chance to win.

sen.j: 墓は東京都品川区光取寺と広島県尾道市光明寺 (尾道市)にある。
sen.e: His graves are in Koshu-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo and in Komyo-ji Temple in Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture.
His graves are in Koshu-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo and in Komyo-ji Temple in Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture.
His graves are in Koshu-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo and in Komyo-ji Temple in Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture.

sen.j: 尚、陣幕という四股名は後に日本相撲協会に拠って年寄名跡『陣幕』として現在に至るまで代々受け継がれている。
sen.e: The sumo wrestler's professional name of Jinmaku was decided to be inherited by Nihon Sumo Kyokai (Japan Sumo Association) and until today, it has been inherited as a professional name of a Toshiyori (retired wrestler) year after year.

The sumo wrestler's professional name of Jinmaku was decided to be inherited by Nihon Sumo Kyokai (Japan Sumo Association) and until today, it has been inherited as a professional name of a Toshiyori (retired wrestler) year after year.

The sumo wrestler's professional name of Jinmaku was decided to be inherited by Nihon Sumo Kyokai (Japan Sumo Association) and until today, it has been inherited as a professional name of a Toshiyori (retired wrestler) year after year.

sen.j: 陣幕久五郎の死去から95年後、昭和の大横綱・千代の富士貢が引退して年寄陣幕を襲名した際、陣幕の故郷である東出雲町では、千代の富士とその師匠である北の富士勝昭を招き、陣幕の顕彰記念行事を催している。
sen.e: 95 years after the death of Kyugoro JINMAKU, when Mitsugu CHIYONOFUJI, the greatest Yokozuna of the Showa period, retired and inherited the name of Toshiyori Jinmaku, at Higashi-Izumo-cho where Jinmaku was born and raised, Chiyonofuji and his master Katsuaki KITANOFUJI were invited and a ceremony to honor Jinmaku was carried out.

Ninety-five years after the death of Kyugoro JINMAKU, when Mitsugu CHIYONOFUJI, the greatest Yokozuna of the Showa period, retired and inherited the name of Jinmaku as Toshiyori, the Jinmaku's hometown Higashi-Izumo-cho invited Chiyonofuji and his master Katsuaki KITANOFUJI and held a ceremony to honor Jinmaku.

Ninety-five years after the death of Kyugoro JINMAKU, when Mitsugu CHIYONOFUJI, the greatest Yokozuna of the Showa period, retired and inherited the name of Jinmaku as Toshiyori, the Jinmaku's hometown Higashi-Izumo-cho invited Chiyonofuji and his master Katsuaki KITANOFUJI and held a ceremony to honor Jinmaku.
